lg.l: I know a certain valley Valley. Possibly the valley of the Water of Leith, or the Leith River, which flows through the South Island city of Dunedin. where the birch Birch. Likely a reference to species of beech, which were originally mistaken for a species of birch, and predominated in hilly and mountainous forests, especially in the South Island. and rata Rata. A species of tree that produces red flowers during the summer. lend
Their stately form and colour to the sky,

Where brambles deck the hollow and ferns Ferns. There are almost two hundred species of fern native to New Zealand, and New Zealand’s forests are unusual due to the dominance of fern species. in grandeur bend
To kiss the gentle stream that eddies by.
I know a rugged footpath where a crazy little bridge
Is built alone to bear the weight of love,
Or glass its rustic beauty in the waters of the ridge,
Or shade them from the azure light above.

I know a sweet November where morning glory Morning glory. Pōwhiwhi, or the New Zealand bindweed, is a perennial vine that grows on forest margins and produces white flowers. The invasive blue morning glory was not introduced into New Zealand until the mid-twentieth century. creeps
Around the heart to while its care away;
A fallen forest monarch entombed in emerald sleeps
Where lovers rest to dream their sweet to-day.
I know these things are transient, for winter comes anon
To claim as withered leaves the rata bud;
But yet a little summer till its loveliness is gone
And gentle streams be ruffled by the flood.
But I know another valley where frost shall never come,
Where rata’s crimson blossoms never die;
For fern and mossy valley in memory have a home
Eternal as the stream that eddies by.
